chapter.title: The &BRAMPUINO1X;
chapter.para:
The &BRAMPUINO1X; is a small device based on the open Arduino hardware platform to make series of shots automatically. In its simpliest setting it acts as a normal intervalometer (this is the default setting).
It can be configured to be used as an HDRI intervalometer as well.
Additionally it can be used as a Bulb Ramper like the Little Bramper.
The &BRAMPUINO1X; is one of the few devices that can bulb ramping and ISO ramping!
We give a short introduction in the required pieces of hardware to build &BRAMPUINO1X; in . These are all off-the-shelf components.
In we list the software that is needed if the source code will be altered and re-compiled.

section.title: Hardware
section.para:
The following hardware is required:
Arduino Uno Rev3
The Arduino Uno Rev3 is the basic platform for this prototype.
USB Host Shield by Circuits@Home
The USB Host Shield talks from the hardware side to the Canon Camera via USB.
The makers of this shield provide libraries to talk to the camera from a software side.
RGB LCD Shield
The RGB LCD Shield by Adafruit with its 5 buttons is interface between &BRAMPUINO1X; and the user.
This shield was used because it uses the I2C-bus and uses less pins than other shields.

chapter.title: Interface
chapter.para: The &BRAMPUINO1X; provides a simple text based interface via the 16x2 RGB LCD shield. It allows to set parameters and start &BRAMPUINO1X;.
In we give the structure to the menu hierarchy with a short explanation and in we show how to navigate with the buttons through the menu.

tip.title: Exposure Offset
tip.para: If you use LiveView with a &CANON5DMKII; then you should set the exposure offset to a value around 200. The camera needs this time to reset the mirror/shutter.

tip.title: Minimal Interval
tip.para: If you use LiveView with a &CANON5DMKII; then you should set the minimal interval to a value around 2000. The camera needs this time for an unknown reason.

tip.title: Move Focus
tip.para: The move focus option does not work reliably with a &CANON5DMKII;. If it works with your camera then report the camera model, the lens and all setting to us, please.

warning.title: Storing Values
warning.para: At the current development status parameter values are not stored in the EEPROM.

section.title: Buttons
section.para: The RGB LCD Shield provides 5 buttons: left, right, up, down and select. To navigate through the menu the buttons have the following meaning:

listitem.para: Return from current menu hierarchy to previous menu hierarchy

section.para:
To change a value selected by navigating through the menu the buttons have the following meaning:
up
Cancel input. The value is not changed.
left
Decrement the value.
right
Increment the value.
select
Store this value and return to previous menu.
If you enter a value and keep the increment or decrement button pressed, it increments or decrements more rapidly.

warning.title: The MX2 controller
warning.para: This navigation is not consistent with the Dynamic Deception MX2 Motion Controller. It will be changed in the future.

section.para:

#3/5 ISO50 B:1057/EV:1.00

The video can be viewed on vimeo.
&BRAMPUINO1X; in action
While &BRAMPUINO1X; is running and taking shots some settings can be changed. The buttons have the following meaning:

listitem.para: Stop shooting. This takes a while till the menu appears.
Decrement the Exposure Value Change by 0.1.
Increment the Exposure Value Change by 0.1.
Enter the menu while &BRAMPUINO1X; is still shooting. All parameters can be changed but not all show an effect. Select Start to return to the running screen.

section.para: When shooting is finished &BRAMPUINO1X; switches the RGB LCD color to green.

chapter.title: Uses of &BRAMPUINO1X;
chapter.para:
The &BRAMPUINO1X; can be used in different contexts if the parameters are set properly.
In any case the &BRAMPUINO1X; must be connected to the camera via an USB-cable.

section.title: &BRAMPUINO1X; as an Intervalometer
section.para: The &BRAMPUINO1X;'s default configuration is to use &BRAMPUINO1X; as a simple intervalometer. Set the Interval parameters as needed.

Set the Exposure time to the correct value X:
Settings Exposure Exp.Time X . Make sure that the minimum and maximum exposure time do not cut the exposure time X.
Set the ISO Min to the correct value I:
Settings ISO ISO Min I .
Alternatively you ca set the Exposure Time to zero. Then the cameras current settings will be used.

Set the Exposure Value Change to 0:
Settings Exposure Exp.EV.Change 0 .

section.title: &BRAMPUINO1X; as a Focus Stacker
section.para: Set parameters as in .

Set the Move Focus to X as needed:
Settings Move Focus Steps X .
Please report camera, lens and all settings if this works.

section.title: &BRAMPUINO1X; in HDRI
section.para: Set parameters as in .

Set the number of shots X as the maximum number of shots:
Settings Max.Exp X

Set the Exp.FPS to 1:
Settings Exposure Exp.FPS 1 .

Set the exposure value increment X per shot in Exposure Value Change:
Settings Exposure Exp.EV.Change X .

section.title: &BRAMPUINO1X; as an Bulb Ramper
section.para: &BRAMPUINO1X; can be used as an Bulb Ramper in day to night and night to day transitions.
Set parameters as in and .

Set the Exposure Value Change X to the exposure value that should be reached after some shots.
Settings Exposure Exp.EV.Change X .

Set the Exposure FPS to the number of shots after which the exposure will be changed by Exposure Value Change exposure values.
Settings Exposure Exp.FPS X .

example.title: Exposure Change Value and FPS
example.para:
If you set the Exposure Time to 1000, the Exposure FPS to 150 and the Exposure Change Value to 4.0 then the exposure will change by 4 Exposure Values and the 151-th shot
will have a 16000 milliseconds exposure time.
The Exposure time for the first then shots are: 1000, 1019, 1038, 1057, 1077, 1097, 1117, 1138, 1159 and 1181.
